bib_record.title: The radiochemical yield in the spontaneous fission of 238U

free_txt: Philips low-level beta-counting assembly type PW 4127
The yields given are the averages of 2 measurements but
the nature of the uncertainty is not given.
.The number of fissions were determined using
the uranium weight and the U-238 spontaneous fission
half life. For calculating the yields, the 8.04E+15
year half life by E.Segre, Phys.Rev.86(1959)21 was
used, as the yields agreed better with other published
values.
COMMENT: The fission yields calculated using the
1.01E+16 yrs half life by R.L.Fleischer and P.B.Price,
Phys.Rev.133(1964)B63 are also given in Table 1 of
J.Inorg.Nucl.Chem.35(1973)1793 but were found to be
discrepant with other data and therefore discarded by
the authors.
. as described in subentries 2 and 3
direct beta counting
natural uranium as reactor-grade U3O8, dissolved in
nitric acid (2N HNO3)
Bib-information and data from J.Inorg.Nucl.Chem.35
The decay curve for the molybdenum activity was
measured for 15 days and found to follow the 67 hr half
life of Mo-99.
A standardised Mo-99 source was used to determine the
counter geometry and required corrections for back-
scattering and the finite shape of the measured source.
The MO-99 yield given in the DATA table is based on the
U-238 spontaneous fission half life of 8.04E+15 years.
The 1.01E+16 years half life would have given a fission
yield for Mo-99 of 7.2+-0.4.
.The solution stood for 21 days to accumulate
fission product molybdenum. Then again Mo carrier was
added and Mo precipitated and purified.
6 l solution containing 3.067 kg of uranium was used.
Mo carrier was added and all molybdenum in the sample
removed chemically.
The decay curve was decomposed into a 20.8 hr
component (I-133) and an 8 day component (I-131).
The counter was calibrated using K2SO4 (as beta
energies of natural potassium are similar to those of
I-133). For self-absorption and backscattering
corrections, a source containing I-133 was produced.
The authors state that their I-131 yield is lower than
that reported by other authors. The reason could be
that their experiment was designed to measure the I-133
yield and they did not allow sufficient time to produce
enough I-131. The discrepancy was probably due to
low counts and poor statistics.
The iodine yields given in the DATA table are based on
the U-238 spontaneous fission half life of 8.04E+15
years. The 1.01E+16 years half life would have given th
following fission yields:
.The solution stood for 8 days to accumulate
fission product iodine. The procedure for purification
from iodine (see SAMPLE above) was repeated. The
extracted solution stood for 2 more days to allow the
short lived iodine isotopes to decay. Then the iodine
was further purified, precipitate as AgI and prepared
for beta counting.
4 l solution containing 4.015 kg of uranium was used.
Chemical procedures were applied and the solution
distilled to remove all iodine already present in the
sample.
